data.title: Summer calendar has it all
data.meta_description: All dates are subject to change
data.text:
By of the

All dates are subject to change

May 7

"Iron Man 2" He's no man of steel, but until they make a great Superman movie, Iron Man is the superhero to beat at the box office. The first film made more than $300 million domestically. Now director Jon Favreau teams up again with Robert Downey Jr., introduces characters played by Mickey Rourke and Scarlett Johansson, and replaces Terrence Howard with Don Cheadle.

May 14

"Just Wright" Romantic sports comedy with Queen Latifah as a physical therapist helping a handsome NBA player, portrayed by Common.

"Letters to Juliet" Amanda Seyfried helps a woman, played by Vanessa Redgrave, reunite with her long-lost love.

"Robin Hood" Before he robbed the rich to help the poor, the bow-slinging legend led a revolt against high taxes. Reunites Russell Crowe and "Gladiator" director Ridley Scott.

May 21

"MacGruber" Another "Saturday Night Live" sketch inflated into a feature-length film, with Will Forte in a parody of TV action hero "MacGyver."

"Shrek Forever After" When he wishes he could go back to being an ordinary ogre, Shrek lands in an alternate "It's A Wonderful Life" type-world.

May 27

"Sex and the City 2" The franchise jumps the shark. Carrie Bradshaw and her girlfriends travel to Abu Dhabi, where they encounter sand, camels, Liza Minnelli and Carrie's old flame, played by John Corbett. Didn't Elvis already make this movie? With Sarah Jessica Parker, Kim Cattrall, Cynthia Nixon, Kristin Davis.

May 28

"Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time" Action fantasy film based on a video game. There are few more frightening words than "produced by Jerry Bruckheimer," but hopefully Mike Newell, director of "Four Weddings and a Funeral" and "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire," has an ace up his sleeve. With Jake Gyllenhaal.

June 4

"Get Him to the Greek" Sequel of sorts to "Forgetting Sarah Marshall," by the same director. This time, the English rock star played by Russell Brand is escorted while on tour by fledgling music executive Jonah Hill.

"Killers" Action romantic comedy, about a just-married government assassin who forgets to tell his new bride about his job. With Ashton Kutcher, Katherine Heigl.

"Marmaduke" "Marley & Me" star Owen Wilson goes from one dog of a movie to this live-action film about a talking canine. Based on the newspaper comic strip.

"Mother and Child" Multi-character narrative about parenthood. Annette Bening is a woman who gave up a child years ago, now an adult played by Naomi Watts, and Kerry Washington is a baker longing for a child. By "Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her" writer-director Rodrigo Garcia.

"Splice" Sundance Film Festival thriller about scientists who combine human and animal DNA. With Sarah Polley, Adrien Brody.

June 11

"The A-Team" Really? And with Liam Neeson? Aw, geez.

"The Karate Kid" Remake of coming-of-age film about a bullied youth who takes martial arts lessons to defend himself. With Jaden Smith, Jackie Chan.

"Please Give" A couple have problems with the granddaughters of a woman who rents an apartment from them. With Rebecca Hall, Catherine Keener, Amanda Peet. Written and directed by Nicole Holofcener.

June 16

"Jonah Hex" Western based on comic book about a physically scarred bounty hunter tracking a Civil War-era terrorist. With Josh Brolin, Megan Fox, John Malkovich.

June 18

"Toy Story 3" Can't-wait film of the summer. When Andy goes to college, the toys of his youth are sent to a day care center. With voices by Tom Hanks, Tim Allen.

June 25

"Knight & Day" Formulaic action comedy with Tom Cruise as a spy whose job protecting a scientist is complicated by Cameron Diaz. By "Walk the Line" director James Mangold.

"Grown Ups" Comedy about childhood buddies who reunite after 30 years. All-star cast includes Adam Sandler, Chris Rock, David Spade, Kevin James and, oh yeah, Rob Schneider.

"Ondine" A loner fisherman rescues a woman from the water, whom his daughter believes is a creature from Irish myth. With Colin Farrell. By writer-director Neil Jordan.

June 30

"The Twilight Saga: Eclipse" Third film about vampires, werewolves and the girls who love them. With Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson and Taylor Lautner.

July 2

"The Last Airbender" A youth with unusual powers must stop the war between the kingdoms of Earth, Air, Water and Fire. Fantasy film based on Nickelodeon cartoon series. By "The Sixth Sense" director M. Night Shyamalan.

"Micmacs" Visually ingenious caper film about a shooting victim who teams up with a group of outcasts to set two arms manufacturers against each other. From "Am√©lie" director Jean-Pierre Jeunet.

July 9

"Coco Chanel and Igor Stravinsky" Lives of the successful fashion designer and the Russian composer living in destitute exile in France intersect. With Mads Mikkelsen, Anna Mouglalis.

"Despicable Me" Animated 3-D comedy about a plot to steal the moon. With voices by Steve Carell, Jason Segel, Julie Andrews.

"I Am Love" The decline of an aristocratic Italian family in a film about the clash between tradition and modernity. With Tilda Swinton.

"Predators" Sequel to "Predator," about a race of killer aliens.

July 16

"Inception" A group of "dream thieves" invades people's minds while they are sleeping and steal their ideas for profit. Could be awful or awfully good. Might be the latter, since it's from "The Dark Knight" and "Memento" writer-director Christopher Nolan. With Leonardo DiCaprio.

"The Sorcerer's Apprentice" A physics student is apprenticed to a sorcerer. With Nicolas Cage, Jay Baruchel.

July 23

"Dinner for Schmucks" A promotion is promised to the man who can bring the biggest dope to a dinner party. Paul Rudd brings Steve Carell. Comedy ensues, but lessons are learned.

"Ramona and Beezus" Selena Gomez is the older sister to a troublemaker, in a family film based on Beverly Cleary's novels for young readers.

"Salt" Angelina Jolie as a CIA agent accused of being a Russian sleeper spy, who goes on the run to clear her name.

July 30

"Charlie St. Cloud" A young, grieving man takes a job at the cemetery where his younger brother is buried. With Zac Efron.

"Beastly" Modern retelling of "The Beauty and the Beast."

"Cats & Dogs: Revenge of Kitty Galore" The animals of the title join forces to defeat a common enemy. Live-action spoof in 3-D.

"Cyrus" Jonah Hill as a youth who loves his mom too much, and John C. Reilly as the man dating her. With Marisa Tomei. Directed by Jay and Mark Duplass.

Aug. 6

"The Other Guys" Buddy cop comedy with Will Ferrell, Mark Wahlberg.

"Step Up 3-D" Third in series of dance-battle films.

Aug. 13

"Eat, Pray, Love" Adaptation of bestseller about a woman's search for happiness after her divorce stars Julia Roberts and Javier Bardem, directed by "Glee" co-creator Ryan Murphy.

"The Expendables" Sylvester Stallone leads a group of mercenaries - including Randy Couture, Terry Crews, Jason Statham and Jet Li - to overthrow a dictator. With appearances by Bruce Willis and Arnold Schwarzenegger.

"Scott Pilgrim vs. the World" Michael Cera plays a rock guitarist who must earn his girlfriend's love by defeating her ex-boyfriends, all of whom are superheroes.

Aug. 20

"Get Low" A hermit played by Robert Duvall wants mortician Bill Murray to arrange his funeral, and invites all his friends to his shack in the woods for a final party. With Sissy Spacek.

"Lottery Ticket" A young man tries to keep his winning lottery ticket a secret from his busybody neighbors. With Bow Wow, Ice Cube.

"Nanny McPhee Returns" Emma Thompson is a magic governess taking care of young troublemakers. With Maggie Gyllenhaal.

" Takers" High-tech bank robbers attempt one last job. With Matt Dillon, Idris Elba, Hayden Christensen, Zoe Saldana.

Aug. 27

"Going the Distance" A young couple try to keep their cross-country romance alive. With Drew Barrymore, Justin Long.
